Data presentation

1. Data collection


ID is: 4288 Seed is: 3501

Grouping data

A clinic sister has recorded the height (in centimetrescentimetres) of 99 patients.

168147155161148157155153140168147155161148157155153140

  1. What is the range of this data set?

    The range of a data set is the difference between the biggest and smallest values in the set. The biggest value can be called 'the maximum' value and the smallest value can be called 'the minimum' value.
    Answer:

    The range of this data set is centimetrescentimetres.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Identify the smallest and biggest values and use them to work out the range of the data.

    STEP: Rank the data, listing the values from smallest to biggest
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    In a large set of numbers, it can be difficult to spot the smallest and biggest numbers. Carefully rank the values you have been given from smallest to biggest, so that you can use the first and last value in the ranked list.

    140140147147148148153153155155155155157157161161168168

    The first value is the smallest value, which is 140140. The last value is the biggest value, which is 168168.

    140140147147148148153153155155155155157157161161168168

    STEP: Use the biggest and smallest value to find the range of the data
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    Range=biggest value−smallest value=168−140=28Range=biggest value−smallest value=168−140=28

    The range is 28 centimetres28 centimetres.

  2. The clinic sister recorded the height measurements of all the 1313 year old patients over a period of a month. The minimum height recorded was 141 cm141 cm, and the maximum height recorded was 167 cm167 cm.

    A lot of data was recorded! The clinic sister decides to group the data into six evenly spread groups so that she can draw a histogram. Which table shows the best option for grouping the data?

    A B
    Height (in cmcm)
    140−142140−142
    143−149143−149
    150−154150−154
    155−158155−158
    159−160159−160
    Height (in cmcm)
    140−145140−145
    145−150145−150
    150−155150−155
    160−165160−165
    165−170165−170
    170−175170−175
    C D
    Height (in cmcm)
    140−144140−144
    145−149145−149
    150−154150−154
    155−159155−159
    160−164160−164
    165−169165−169
    Height (in cmcm)
    130−139130−139
    140−149140−149
    150−159150−159
    160−169160−169
    170−179170−179
    180−189180−189
    Answer:

    The table with the best grouping is Table .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Some of these group choices are not ideal. Think about how the data values would fit into the listed groups. Pick the most sensible grouping.

    STEP: Decide which grouping is best
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    These are some of the things to consider:

    • The table should have six classes.
    • The classes should have equal class intervals. 'Evenly spread' means each class should be the same size.
    • Classes should not overlap or it will be unclear where to place certain values.
    • Can all values between 141 cm141 cm and 167 cm167 cm be placed into these groups?
    • Are any of the groups in the table not needed?
    A ✘ Only five data classes are listed, and they have unequal class intervals, meaning some classes are bigger than others. Also, the last class ends too soon, so there is no class for values bigger than 160 cm160 cm.
    B ✘ 145 cm145 cm could be placed in both Class 11 and Class 22! These classes are overlapping, which is incorrect. Also there is a 'gap' in the middle of this table; the class 155−160155−160 is missing.
    C ✔ This has six equally spread classes which do not overlap.
    D ✘ Three of the classes would have no values. It is okay to have a frequency of zero for a class, but it would not be sensible for the first class to be smaller than your smallest recorded height or for the last class to be bigger than your biggest recorded height.
    Submit your answer as:

51.854.940.243.041.350.353.060.451.641.151.854.940.243.041.350.353.060.451.641.1

  1. What is the range of this data set?

    The range of a data set is the difference between the biggest and smallest values in the set. The biggest value can be called 'the maximum' value and the smallest value can be called 'the minimum' value.
    Answer:

    The range of this data set is kilogramskilograms.

    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>

    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    40.240.241.141.141.341.343.043.050.350.351.651.651.851.853.053.054.954.960.460.4

    The first value is the smallest value, which is 40.240.2. The last value is the biggest value, which is 60.460.4.

    40.240.241.141.141.341.343.043.050.350.351.651.651.851.853.053.054.954.960.460.4

    STEP: Use the biggest and smallest value to find the range of the data

  2. The clinic sister recorded the weight measurements of all the 1313 year old patients over a period of a month. The minimum weight recorded was 43.9 kg43.9 kg, and the maximum weight recorded was 63.6 kg63.6 kg.

    A lot of data was recorded! The clinic sister decides to group the data into six evenly spread groups so that she can draw a histogram. Which table shows the best option for grouping the data?

    A B
    Weight (in kgkg)
    20<w≤3020<w≤30
    30<w≤4030<w≤40
    40<w≤5040<w≤50
    50<w≤6050<w≤60
    60<w≤7060<w≤70
    70<w≤8070<w≤80
    Weight (in kgkg)
    40<w≤4440<w≤44
    44<w≤4844<w≤48
    48<w≤5248<w≤52
    52<w≤5652<w≤56
    56<w≤6056<w≤60
    60<w≤6460<w≤64
    C D
    Weight (in kgkg)
    40−4440−44
    45−4945−49
    50−5450−54
    55−5955−59
    60−6460−64
    Weight (in kgkg)
    40≤w≤4340≤w≤43
    43≤w≤4643≤w≤46
    46≤w≤4946≤w≤49
    49≤w≤5249≤w≤52
    52≤w≤5552≤w≤55
    55≤w≤5855≤w≤58
    Answer:

    The table with the best grouping is Table .

    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Some of these group choices are not ideal. Think about how the data values would fit into the listed groups. Pick the most sensible grouping.

    STEP: Decide which grouping is best
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    These are some of the things to consider:

    • The table should have six classes.
    • The classes should have equal class intervals. 'Evenly spread' means each class should be the same size.
    • Classes should not overlap or it will be unclear where to place certain values.
    • Can all values between 43.9 kg43.9 kg and 63.6 kg63.6 kg be placed into these groups?
    • Are any of the groups in the table not needed?
    A ✘ If we sort like this, three of the classes would have no values. It is okay to have a frequency of zero for a class, but it is not sensible for the first class to be smaller than the smallest weight or for the last class to be bigger than the biggest weight.
    B ✔ This has six equally spread classes, each with a class interval of 4 kg4 kg. The classes do not overlap.
    C ✘ Only five data classes are listed. Also it will not be possible to put certain decimal weights into these groups. For example 44.8 kg44.8 kg will not fit into Class 11 or Class 22.
    D ✘ These classes are overlapping. 43 kg43 kg could be placed in Class 11 and Class 22! One value cannot be placed in two classes. Also, the last class ends too soon so there is no class in which to put weights bigger than 58 kg58 kg.

ID is: 4281 Seed is: 4235

Data collection options

Mcebisi wants to answer the following question:

Is my baby crying too much?

Choose the best way to collect data to answer this question.

Answer:

The best way to collect this data is:

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Decide which will be the best way to answer this question.

STEP: Choose the most sensible method of data collection
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
✔ observations
Observations are the best method of collecting data when you need to look at behaviours.
✘ a questionnaire
Questionnaires are the best method of collecting data when you want to collect responses from a group of people and you want to see general results. A questionnaire has a set of clear questions, usually with a choice of answers.
✘ a census
A census is when data is collected about every person in a country. For example, information about every person is needed when planning roads, parks, hospitals, schools transport, and big structures that affect every person.

It is not always sensible to ask questions in a questionnaire or an interview or a census. Babies can't talk, so they can't answer questions. Answers to questions like these are best seen rather than answered in words.

So we should use observations to find out:

Is my baby crying too much?
Submit your answer as:

ID is: 4281 Seed is: 6331

Data collection options

Riaan wants to answer the following question:

How many people live in our country?

Choose the best way to collect data to answer this question.

Answer:

The best way to collect this data is:

HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Decide which will be the best way to answer this question.

STEP: Choose the most sensible method of data collection
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
✘ an interview
An interview (such as a job interview or a parent-teacher interview) is a formal or informal conversation between two or more people. An interview should have clear questions that can be answered in many ways. It can be done either in person, over the telephone, or on the computer.
✘ observations
Observations are the best method of collecting data when you need to look at behaviours.
✔ a census
A census is when data is collected about every person in a country. For example, information about every person is needed when planning roads, parks, hospitals, schools transport, and big structures that affect every person.

The only way to find out how many people live in the country is to count the entire population. This is done through a census. In a census, the government hires thousands of people to knock on the door of every single household in the country and ask them questions about how many people live in each household.

So we should use a census to find out:

How many people live in our country?
Submit your answer as:

Surveys & frequencies

Answer the following questions about surveys.

  1. Select the statement that is false about conducting a survey:

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    One of the three statements is false. Which one?

    STEP: Read the statements and identify which is false
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    A survey is a way of collecting data from a representative sample of people. A survey can be conducted in many ways, for example: the survey questions can be asked in a personal or telephonic interview, or by using a written or electronic questionnaire. A response is collected from each participant. Once all the data is collected, it is possible to look at the collected responses and make sense of what these results mean.

    These are both true statements:

    ✔ Ask all participants the same survey question(s).
    ✔ A questionnaire is a set of questions used for the purposes of a survey.

    This statement is false:

    ✘ A survey must always be conducted in English.

    This statement is false because a survey can be conducted in any language, provided the respondents understand the questions.

    Submit your answer as:

    250250 or more 145145

    2. How many students, in total, were surveyed?

    1. The number of students who completed fewer than 150150 exercises is .
    2. The total number of students who completed the survey is .
    numeric
    numeric
    2 attempts remaining
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

    Add up the correct frequencies from the table to answer the question.

    STEP: Select and add the correct frequencies to answer this question
    [−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

    We are interested in all the frequencies where the number of exercises completed was less than 150150.

    Number of exercises this term Frequency
    fewer than 5050 180180
    50−9950−99 150150
    100−149100−149 110110
    150−199150−199 105105
    200−249200−249 4545
    250250 or more 145145

    Frequencies we need from the table

    =180+150+110=440=180+150+110=440
    STEP: Calculate how many students, in total, took part in the survey
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

    One response was recorded for each student who took part in the survey. So, to find out how many people were surveyed, we must add up all the frequencies listed in the table.

    Total number of people surveyed=180+150+110+105+45+145=735Total number of people surveyed=180+150+110+105+45+145=735

ID is: 4293 Seed is: 3236

Surveys & frequencies

Answer the following questions about surveys.

  1. Select the statement that is false about conducting a survey:

    Answer:
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    One of the three statements is false. Which one?

    STEP: Read the statements and identify which is false
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]
    A survey is a way of collecting data from a representative sample of people. A survey can be conducted in many ways, for example: the survey questions can be asked in a personal or telephonic interview, or by using a written or electronic questionnaire. A response is collected from each participant. Once all the data is collected, it is possible to look at the collected responses and make sense of what these results mean.

    These are both true statements:

    ✔ Ask each participant the survey questions(s) only once.
    ✔ A survey can be conducted in any language.

    This statement is false:

    ✘ A survey can only include one question.

    This statement is false because more than one question may be asked - often a survey is conducted with a questionnaire containing several questions.

    Submit your answer as:

ID is: 4278 Seed is: 481

Understanding data collection

Asking the right questions is an important part of the data handling process. If you don’t ask a good question at first, you won’t collect good answers.

7 Steps in Data Handling Process
1 Ask a good question
2 Decide how to collect data
3 Collect raw data
4 Organise the data
5 Represent (show) the data
6 Interpret (explain) the data
7 Answer, predict, and ask more

    People should always be told why they are being asked questions, so that they:

    • are not afraid to answer truthfully, and
    • are not misled into answering in a certain way.

    Let's assume that people have been told that we need someone to paint the school buildings.

    NOTE: Neutral questions are good. Biased questions are not good.
    Neutral Questions: When a car is not in forward gear or reverse gear, we say it is in neutral. When a question is not strongly supporting something or strongly encouraging something, we say it is a neutral question. This is a good style of question because people feel free to choose their answer.
    Biased Questions: The word biased means unfair. Biased questions are those that one could think of as a car not in neutral but in forward gear or reverse gear. This is not a good style of question, because people feel persuaded to answer their question in a certain way.

    Adebiyi's question is neutral, clear, specific, and it can be answered with a variety of clear answers.

Classes & class intervals

An outdoor tree-climbing facility has rules about which climbing courses are safe to climb according to your age.

Age Course
3−53−5 years Twig course
6−96−9 years Monkey course
10−1410−14 years Tarzan course
15−2015−20 years Hi-ho course
21−8021−80 years Adults course

Answer the following questions:

Answer:
  1. How many classes are listed?
  2. Are the class intervals all equal?
  3. For the third class, the class interval is year(s).
  4. A person aged 77 years would be able to climb the .
one-of
type(string.nocase)
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 7 / 7 points left]

Count the number of age categories shown in the table. Do all the age categories cover the same number of years?

STEP: Look carefully at the rows in the table
[−2 points ⇒ 5 / 7 points left]
It is helpful to organise large amounts of data into categories called classes. The size of a class is called the class interval.

Each row (under the top heading) shows an age category called a class.

Class Age Course
1 3−53−5 years Twig course
2 6−96−9 years Monkey course
3 10−1410−14 years Tarzan course
4 15−2015−20 years Hi-ho course
5 21−8021−80 years Adults course

There are 55 classes.

STEP: Check the size of each class
[−2 points ⇒ 3 / 7 points left]

In this diagram we can see that Class 11 (the children whose ages are between 33 and 55 years) has a class interval of three years.

For Class 11 we can say:

  • The size of the class is 33 years.
  • The width of the class is 33 years.
  • The class interval is 33 years.

All of these statements mean the same thing.

Class 11 is four years wide and Class 22 is three years wide, so the class intervals are not all equal.

NOTE: It is often sensible to have equal class intervals. But with data like age-specific physical ability, this development does not happen at the same rate every year. A child develops enormously between the age of one and two but there is not the same degree of physical development between the age of nine and ten for example. For this reason, the age categories here do not have the same class interval.
STEP: Determine the size of the third class
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 7 points left]

Class 33 in the diagram above is children who are 10−1410−14 years old, which means:

  1. Children who are 1010 years old
  2. Children who are 1111 years old
  3. Children who are 1212 years old
  4. Children who are 1313 years old
  5. Children who are 1414 years old

So, this class spans a period of 55 years.

STEP: Check which class this age falls into
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 7 points left]

The table lists the names of the classes; Class 22 is the Monkey course, therefore a person aged 77 years would be able to climb the Monkey course.

Introduction to tally marks

Daniel counted the number of girls playing tennis, and used tally marks to show this raw data.

What is the frequency total?

Answer:

The frequency total is .

numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

STEP: Count up the tally marks
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]
Tally marks are a useful way to collect data. Short vertical lines are used to quickly mark items as you count them. When we add up all the tally marks, it tells us the frequency (how many times the event occurred). To make reading the tally marks easier, every fifth mark is written as a diagonal line followed by a space to separate each group of five. Here are some examples of correct tally markings:
33
44
55
88
1010
1212

We were given the following tally marks:

In this case, the frequency of girls playing tennis = 55.

Summarizing numbers in tally charts

A tally chart provides a quick method of recording data as events happen. Here is an example of a tally chart for something that happened 88 times. There is 11 group of five and 33 individual strokes.

Imagine you make a tally chart for the number of students taking the bus and you find the total number is 22. Your tally chart will have pieces, something like this:

Answer:

For a tally chart which shows 22 tallies, how many groups of five and how many individual strokes will you have?

  • Groups of 5:
  • Individual strokes:
numeric
numeric
2 attempts remaining
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The tally chart you constructed should look something like the one below:

Each item is represented by a vertical or a diagonal stroke. We make 44 vertical strokes. Then every fifth observation is represented by a diagonal line crossing the previous four to make a five-barred gate. It's easier for our eyes to see 00 group(s) of five and 22 individual stroke(s) than if they where all vertical strokes. We can just multiply the number of groups of five by 55 and add the individual ones.

5×0+2=25×0+2=2

This gives you the frequency of 22.

The correct answers are 00 groups of five and 22 individual strokes.

ID is: 3151 Seed is: 2910

Working with the range of a data set

Determine the minimum value in a data set if the maximum value in the data set is 5757 and the range of the data is 1919.

Answer: The minimum value is .
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Remember that the range is the difference between the largest and smallest values in a data set.
STEP: Use the range to find the answer
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

The range of a data set tells us how spread out the data are: it is the difference between the largest and smallest values. In this question, we do not know what the data values are, but we know that the range of the data is 1919. We also know that the maximum value is 5757.

We can solve this question using the equation for the range:

range = maximum - minimumrange = maximum - minimum

However, for this solution let's think through the information that we have. The maximum value in the data set is 5757 and the range is 1919. So the minimum value is 1919 below 5757.

minimum = maximum - range=57−19=38minimum = maximum - range=57−19=38

The minimum value is 3838.

The range of a data set tells us how spread out the data are: it is the difference between the largest and smallest values. In this question, we do not know what the data values are, but we know that the range of the data is 77. We also know that the minimum value is 66.

However, for this solution let's think through the information that we have. The minimum value in the data set is 66 and the range is 77. So the maximum value is 77 more than 66.

  • Organise the data

Working with the mean

A group of 55 friends each have some sweets. They work out that the mean number of sweets they have is 66. Then 22 friends leave with an unknown number (xx) of sweets. The remaining 33 friends work out that the mean number of sweets they have left is 66.

How many sweets (xx) were taken away from the group?

Answer:

The number of sweets taken away is .

numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]
Use the formula for the mean to figure out the total number of sweets in the original group.
STEP: Find the total number of sweets at the beginning
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We know that the mean number of sweets the group originally had was 66. Since there are 55 people in the group we can find the total number of sweets in the beginning using the formula for the mean:

mean=(number ofsweets (before))group sizenumber ofsweets (before)=mean×group size=(6)×(5)=30mean=(number ofsweets (before))group sizenumber ofsweets (before)=mean×group size=(6)×(5)=30
STEP: Find the total number of sweets after the 2 people leave
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

We are then told that 22 people leave. After that, the mean number of sweets left is 66. We can then find out how many sweets remain.

mean=(number ofsweets (after))group sizenumber ofsweets (after)=mean×group size=(6)×(3)=18mean=(number ofsweets (after))group sizenumber ofsweets (after)=mean×group size=(6)×(3)=18
STEP: Find the number of sweets taken from the group
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we can work out the number of sweets which were taken from the original group.

number ofsweets removed=items before−items after=(30)−(18)=12number ofsweets removed=items before−items after=(30)−(18)=12

The correct answer is 1212 sweets.

STEP: Determine the median

We need to calculate the median.

First order the data set:

1;3;3;7;78;12;12;12;12;151;3;3;7;78;12;12;12;12;15

The median of a data set is the value in the central position, when the data set has been arranged from the lowest to the highest value. If we have an uneven number of values in the data list, we just look for the middle value.

The median of the data is: 88.

Calculating degrees for a sector in a pie chart

Answer the two questions below about this pie chart.

  1. Calculate the missing value represented by xx.
  2. How many degrees is sector xx? (Round your answer to two decimal places)
Answer:
  2. °°
one-of
type(fraction.unsimplified)
numeric
2 attempts remaining
STEP: Find the value of xx
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

Remember the “pie” represents some kind of whole, which is made up of the slices. Add up all the slices and we get the complete pie. Here the slices known as sectors are divided into values represented as fractions. All the fractions have the same denominator; thus, to get whole "pie", we need to end up with a value like this: 23232323. This evaluates to 1, the whole pie. So xx will be 223223.

STEP: Find the size of sector xx
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

To find the number of degrees a sector should be in a pie chart you can follow these steps:

  • Find the total amount used in the data in this case it was 23
  • What ratio of this total is represented by this sector? Here it was 223223
  • Multiply your ratio with 360 °° (Remember a full revolution = 360 °°)
Sector°=223×360°=31,3°Sector°=223×360°=31,3°

So xx has a fraction value of 223223, which is the same as 31,3°°.

Pie charts

The following statistics are related to the amount of drinking water consumed in different districts in South Africa. (These values are made up values and not a real representation of this event).

  1. Which district uses the most water?
  2. Which district uses the least water?
  3. What is the range of drinking water consumption between the districts?
Answer:
  1. The district which uses the most water is
  2. The district which uses the least water is
  3. The range is %%
numeric
2 attempts remaining
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

For Questions 1 and 2, you can read the answers off of the pie chart. For Question 3 you must do one calculation to get the answer.

STEP: Read off the information you need from the pie chart
[−2 points ⇒ 2 / 4 points left]

For these answers we just need to read the correct answer from the pie chart. The legend corresponds with the sectors by colour. So when we are looking for the highest value, we need to find the highest percentage on the pie chart. Then we check in the legend which name corresponds with the colour of that sector.

The district with the greatest water consumption is Amatole because it has the largest percentage (46%46%). And the district with the lowest water consumption is Cacadu because it has the smallest percentage (12%12%).

STEP: Use the maximum and minimum values to find the range
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

For Question 3 we need to calculate the range. Remember the range is calculated by taking the highest value from the data and subtracting the lowest value from that.

Range=Highest value - Lowest value=46−12=34%Range=Highest value - Lowest value=46−12=34%

Therefore:

  1. The district which uses the most water is Amatole.
  2. The district which uses the least water is Cacadu.
  3. The range is 3434%%.
